metadata.h1: What is Graphical Excellence and How to Create it

all_paragraphs: Let’s say you have 4 of these data sets collected from 4 different sources. You want to see how different they are from one another.

You find out that they are described by exactly the same linear model. There is no difference in the number of data, mean of X’s, mean of Y’s, equation of regression line, standard error, correlation coefficient, and so on. If you are about to make the conclusion that these data sets are identical, delay that temptation and take 5' to graph these data points before making any conclusion.

Their graphical displays are significantly different! This is the exact reason why graphing is so important. When we hear about data, we often think about the representation as numbers. But numbers and calculations are not enough to show insights of data. In order not to make the wrong conclusion, we need not be blinded by statistics alone.
But is any kind of graph significant? The answer is no. This leads us to the definition of graphical excellence.

If you are still not convinced that these criteria are important for an excellent graph, we will go through the examples where these criteria apply with 2 of the most commonly used graphs in data science: map and time series
There are now many tools for us to visualize data with maps. But the maps that are really useful do not need to be fancy and colorful but to show the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time.
Early and most worthy use of a map is the famous dot map of Dr. John to show the locations of deaths from cholera in central London for September 1854.

Deaths were marked by dots and the locations of eleven water pumps were marked by crosses. By examining the scatter over the surface of the map, Snow observed that cholera occurred almost entirely among those who lived near the water pumps. Thus, he had the handle of the contaminated pump removed.

Such a small observation from looking at the map ended the epidemic which had taken more than 500 lives and saved thousands of more future lives! Of course, the links between the pump and the diseases can be easily revealed by any computation. But this map is a powerful example to prove that sometimes the graphical analysis can testify the data far more efficiently than any calculation.

The time-series plot is one of the most frequently used forms of data science. One dimension marches along to the rhythm of seconds, minutes, hours, days, weeks, months, years, centuries. This ordering of the time scale gives this graph the strength and efficiency of interpretation found in no other graphic arrangement.
When hearing about the time-series graph, we often think about this kind of graph:
In fact, the graph above is the most commonly used kind of time-series graph. But do you know that time-series graph can also look like this:

The explanatory power of time-series displays is enhanced when adding spatial dimensions to the design of the graphic. The graph above is the classic of Charles Joseph Minard, showing the terrible fate of Napoleon’s army in Russia. There are several things to notice in the above graph:

The combination of data maps and time-series efficiently portrays a sequence of devastating losses suffered in Napoleon’s Russian campaign. It was a bitterly cold winter and many froze on the march out of Russia. If we are told that the size of the army was initially 422, 000 and ended with 10, 000, we may not really perceive the huge number of the losses. But by looking at the graph, we could vividly visualize what the man came through and how severe the cold was.

This article does not exhaustively show every criterion of an excellent graph. But I hope this article gives you an important message: an excellent graph is not the graph that displays beautiful designs with advanced graphing technology. An excellent graph is one that consists of complex ideas communicated with clarity, precision, and efficiency. An excellent graph gives the viewers the greatest number of ideas in the shortest time in the smallest space. An excellent graph tells the truth about the data.
Thus, when graphing, first define the purpose and the ideas you want to convey through your graph, then find the way to present your ideas.
